I have been going to Hoi A for many years now and have got to know the owner and her staff very well. Every year I have bought something or had an item  - or two -  specially made. Mandy, the owner has excellent knowledge and can help you with the design. Her jeweller can make anything and I mean anything! This year I inherited some old gold charms from my mother in law and a chipped diamond! I had seen a lovely bangle in a high end store in London so they copied it for me. Mandy was away for the weekend so I met with Ngoc her excellent assistant. She was great helping with the finer details. They will give a price which is very fair and very good value to what you would pay in the U.K. Please do not haggle, it is not that kind of shop. I gave my mobile number and they kept in touch informing me when the work was completed so I could collect it. I was absolutely thrilled with it, even better than I had anticipated. A bonus, there was enough gold left from the charms so I had a Raindance style ring made using different sized zirconias. It is stunning. The bangle only took 2 days and the ring 4 days, how brilliant is that. If you are in Hoi An  - or the area -  go at the beginning of your stay then they will have the time to do the work you want. They have a huge stock of beautiful gold and silver items and jade too, if there is a ring you like there they will alter the size which can often be done in 24 hours. Recently they have stocked a big selection of Van Cleef and Arpels style necklaces and bracelets  -  I bought one of those last year -  and it has been admired by many friends. If you want something a little different they will be able to make it I am sure, just take a photo or talk about what you want and they can sketch it for you to give you ideas. Mandy, Ngoc and her staff speak excellent English so there will be no language problem. I would like to take this opportunity to thank Mandy, Ngoc and the jeweller for all the beautiful things you have made for me over the years and hopefully see you all again next year. My sister in law has taken a fancy to my bangle and I think I shall be taking some more gold she has to be melted down for another bangle and maybe another Van Cleef and Arpels style necklace.Read more

So I - ve left this comment trail  - fester -  in cyber-space for some months.   I will now try to address the issues- but as a warning- this explanation will be long.   If Declan is a sincerely interested in jewellery, then Declan you should appreciate this thorough response -  if Declan isn - t prepared to look at the issues described and is only looking for a 20 word sound-bite; then Declan is an internet Troll and nothing I can say will satisfy his need to troll.   Hopefully others will appreciate the information below.  It - s not spin.. it - s the truth as we see it.  
By way of introduction, my name is Phil, I am Australian, my Vietnamese wife Thi Man  - Mandy -  owns Lotus Jewellery.  People expect that Lotus Jewellery is some kind of chain of jewellery stores, we are in fact a small family business.  Ten years ago we taught ourselves the jewellery business, and were lucky enough to form a lasting business relationship with the best silver-smith - gold - smith in the district, who works for us exclusively.  We have no marketing department, no spin-doctors.. we are people who design and manufacture beautiful jewellery  offered at prices tourists can afford.  What we do is far more complex than most western jewellery stores who order via a catalogue or a visiting sales rep, or simply offer the range of jewellery that head office prescribes.   We are enthusiastic about jewellery- and we believe this is evidenced by the huge number of positive reviews we get on Tripadvisor, and the thousands of customers who purchase from us each year.
We regularly manufacture jewellery for people who walk in with a design- often some vague scribbled drawing or a much loved piece that has broken, and they walk out a few days later with a finished piece at an affordable price.  As a westerner I understand how you simply cannot do that in the west.  Yet people still like to criticize us -  so here is our honest response.. for Declan and anyone else who is interested..
Manufacturing Jeweller-   At our store we design and manufacture jewellery.   As few westerners have any experience with manufacturing these days, I will explain some things.   We make jewellery but we have no ability to cut or polish stones.  The job of cutting and polishing stones is done by a Lapidary.   So the jewellery we sell is either manufactured by a third party, or manufactured by ourselves using stones that are already cut and polished.   Some of these stones are cheap and some are expensive.   To get a gemstone appraised in Vietnam costs around US - 40 in Saigon by an SJC Gemologist  - another specialist job -  -  the SJC is the  Saigon Jewellery Company.   We have thousands of gemstones, and a good number in the more expensive range come with an SJC certificate.   Any customer can request a certificate to be issued for any stone in our store, the cost will be US - 40 and the process takes 7-10 days.   No one in their right mind would request a  - 40 certificate for any item selling much less than  - 100- so in those instances we make our best guess regarding the nature of the gemstone.  We are jewellery manufacturers.. not Lapidaries or Gemologists.  We do have experience and contacts in these fields though.
Simulants  -  In the jewellery business world-wide -  including my home country of Australia and Declan - s home country -  jewellery stores sell jewellery incorporating  - simulants -  in the budget priced jewellery segment.  Cheap Turquoise jewellery  is often Dyed Howlite or even worse sometimes resin. In my own home country of Australia there are dozens of Opal shops that sell to tourists on the Gold Coast.  They sell Opal rings for  - 50 or  - 100.   Nowhere in their stores do they advertise that the opals are synthetic opals  - resin - , and really no customer should expect that their opals are rare gems as a quality opal costs hundreds or thousands of dollars.   In our store in Hoi An we also sell opal jewellery, we have no synthetic opal, we have opal triplets, slices of opal from  - Lightening Ridge -  set in a triplet.  To understand what a triplet is  -  I suggest you google.   I mention this as we strive to source actual stones- not synthetic  - resin -  stones.  Beautiful stones simply don - t walk into our store -  we hunt them down.. it - s a difficult job but we enjoy it.  And most of what we sell we manufacture.. often hand-made -  unlike the West where mass produced Asian manufactured goods are prolific.
Jade on display at our store-   We do not  - advertise Green Agate as Jade - .   We have a Jade jewellery cabinet and in that cabinet is a small poster outlining the folk-lore around Jade.   Perhaps less than 10 -  of our stock, our cheap pieces  - under say  - 22 -  sometimes aren - t manufactured by us, they are mass produced designs and some of these we believe to be green agate, so it - s not just our store that sells green agate as a Jade simulant, but thousands of jewellery stores world wide.  Over 80 -  of the jade we have on display is jewellery jade pieces hand-made by our craftsman. We spend hours hand-picking polished stones.  Our jeweller spends perhaps 3x the time as our competitors manufacturing each piece to perfection, and we charge more than our competitors for these  - perfect pieces - . 
We do sell pieces as cheap as  - 30 which are local jewellery jade and hand made with silver.   We also have dozens of pieces that come with an SJC certificate verifying the stone, but these pieces sell for more than  - 100 as I - ve already explained the certification process costs  - 40.    We also have some pieces in the Jade cabinet that are clearly not Jade.  If it - s not green-ish -  it - s not Jade.   We have to put these  - orphan pieces -  somewhere in our store.. so some live in the jade cabinet.  So not knowing specifically which  - 40 piece you asked the shop-girl about -  most of the jewellery in the jade cupboard is Jade -  some is very good Jade from Myanmar -  some is the kind of jewellery Jade you see in Hoi An, but we hand pick every single piece and only buy and use the best stones we can source.  And some cheap items are mass produced Green Agate jewellery sold as a Jade simulant all over the world.      On the subject of  - Green Agate advertised as Jade -  -  we also have a cabinet with cut gemstone jewellery.. in that cabinet we have small posters for Amethyst and Citrine;  which gives the  - folk lore -  of those stones.   That - s not to imply that ALL the stones in that cabinet are Amethyst and Citrine.. the blue stones are Blue Topaz, the light brown ones are smoky quartz..  and there are other coloured stones present -  Garnets etc.. we - ve never felt the need to explain all this- because the jewellery buying public tend to know these things.  Somehow in Declan - s mind  -  he  focuses on our Jade cabinet.  Some items in the Jade cabinet aren - t Jade.  We are a jewellery store not a museum.
About Jade- the best Jade comes from Myanmar.   Myanmar borders with China.   It is the Chinese that love and buy Jade.   We - ve purchased Jade from the Jade market in Myanmar and have some knowledge in this area.   Most high quality Jade  is priced way beyond what westerners can afford or are prepared to pay for Jade.
